How to convert a string to an integer?

I am trying to convert a string to an integer. I saw this in SO, but I can't get it to work.
int a = atoi(str);

I have this in my code:
int a = atoi(str);
int b = atoi(str);

atoi can interpret the number as a number, which is not what I want.

A:

You can use the strtol function to convert a string to an int and you can use strtol to return the result.
int a = atoi(str);
int b = atoi(str);
strtol(a, &a, 0);
strtol(b, &b, 0);

You can also use strtol() with a locale (like C/C++ or Java).

– Newsletter

Here is a complete list of all the women who have been influential in the development of computing. This list is not comprehensive. It is intended to provide a snapshot of the events of the 20th century and can be edited as time goes on.

10. Ethel F. Baskerville (1899 – 1971)

Baskerville was born in Kansas City, Missouri, to a family of German Jews.

Baskerville spent her early years in the Kansas City area and was a student of Julian Baskerville, who was also her father’s tutor. The two met at a conference in Berlin in 1916, and Baskerville began her career at IBM. She was the first woman to join a board of directors for the company.

After her father’s death, she became a full-time computer scientist, and was the first woman to receive a PhD in computer science from the University of Pittsburgh.

Baskerville was married to mathematician Alfred Baskerville. They had two sons, Alfred Baskerville Jr. and Arthur Baskerville.

9. Lucy M. Cooper (1900 – 1983)

M. Cooper was an English teacher and a member of the British delegation to the World Zionist Congress in California, USA.

M. Cooper was the daughter of the British agent in India, Arthur Cooper. She was born in London, England.

M. Cooper was a member of the International Women’s Science League. She was a member of the Organization of American Universities (OAU) and was the editor of the journal, “Science and Society” in 1928.

M. Cooper was the first woman to receive a Ph.D in physics at the University of California, Berkeley, and was a member of the International Bureau for International Education (IBIE).

8. Ethel L. Cavell (1899 – 1970)

Cavell was born into an English family in Stamford, Connecticut, USA. Her father was a clothier and her mother a school teacher.

Cavell received her B.S. degree in English at the University of Connecticut in 1919. She worked in the W.W. Norton & Company office in New York City from 1919 until she retired in 1965.

Cavell co-founded the International Board of Teachers, and later served as the first woman to serve on a board of directors for the American Astronomical Society
